repo.name: ansible
repo.description: Ansible is a radically simple IT automation platform that makes your applications and systems easier to deploy and maintain. Automate everything from code deployment to network configuration to cloud management, in a language that approaches plain English, using SSH, with no agents to install on remote systems. https://docs.ansible.com.

readme.summary: Excellent high-level clarity but lacks concrete examples, quick start code, and configuration guidance for actual usage.
readme.top_issue: No quick start example showing actual Ansible commands or playbook syntax - just links to external documentation

injection_risks.description: The use of shlex.split() on user-controlled input (wrapped_cmd) may lead to command injection vulnerabilities.
The use of subprocess.Popen with a list of arguments constructed from user-controlled input (cmd) may lead to command injection vulnerabilities if not properly sanitized.

critical_findings: Potential command injection vulnerabilities in async_wrapper.py
security.summary: The provided code has potential security risks, including command injection vulnerabilities and insufficient input validation, which require attention to ensure the security of the Ansible package.

common_complaints: Warnings/noise in output that cannot be silenced (reserved variable names, lookup errors)
Feature requests languishing for years without resolution (register expressions, test coverage replacement)
Regressions between versions affecting existing workflows
Inconsistent behavior across Python versions and environments
sentiment.summary: Ansible shows mixed community health with active bug fixes but stalled feature development, legacy issues from 2019-2020 still unresolved, and some regression concerns affecting upgrade paths.

red_flags: some responses come across as slightly abrupt or dismissive
redirects to external forums without fully addressing the issue
communication.summary: The maintainers provide clear and technically sound explanations, but could improve on patience and welcomingness when dealing with user questions and basic issues.

concerns: No commits in past 6 months despite active issue tracking
876 open issues with no recent closures indicates backlog not being addressed
Zero merged PRs in past 6 months suggests no active development
No active contributors in past 6 months
Unknown last release date raises questions about version management
positive_signals: Issues are still being tracked (876 open), indicating some project awareness
Last commit exists (2026-01-13), showing very recent activity
maintenance.summary: Ansible shows signs of stagnation with no development activity over 6 months, despite a recent commit, suggesting the project may be in maintenance-freeze or experiencing upstream issues.

analysis_summary.doc_summary: The README provides a good introduction to Ansible and its features, but lacks concrete examples and troubleshooting guidance.
concerns: Docs: Lack of quick start example or basic usage demonstration
Communication: some responses come across as slightly abrupt or dismissive
Communication: redirects to external forums without fully addressing the issue
Security: Potential command injection vulnerabilities in async_wrapper.py
Security: The use of shlex.split() on user-controlled input (wrapped_cmd) may lead to command injection vulnerabilities.
highlights: steady issue and PR resolution rate
